On 8/7/06, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
>
> My sinser=
e apologies to you C=E9dric, I didn't realise that the
> statement that ups=
et me was not written by you. I jumped to my guns
> too quickly.


Thanks f=
or posting this rectification, Joakim, I appreciate.

Look, I'm trying to b=
uild a bridge here.

On one hand, we have a small (very small) population o=
f people who've put
testing at the forefront of every single engineering ta=
sk they undertake
every day at the exclusion of anything else.

On the othe=
r hand, we have the "rest of the world", which is slowly waking
up to the v=
alues of automated testing but is also dealing with massive code
bases that=
 were not only *not* designed for automated testing, but for which
automate=
d testing might simply be impossible to implement (and yes, I can
come up w=
ith a few examples that will make the most radical TDD
practitioners go ver=
y humble).

I don't have anything to sell here.  I'm not a consultant, I do=
n't get paid
if you use TestNG or if you do more automated testing.  But I'=
ve worked on
both sides of the fence:  I love testing, I like TDD to a cert=
ain extent,
but I'm also seeing a few flaws and gaps in reality between wha=
t I read and
the rest of the industry, and because of that, I feel that I c=
an offer a
perspective that both sides can relate to.

When somebody posts =
on this mailing-list asking for help because they can't
follow to the lette=
r principles explained in extreme books, I feel as a
personal obligation to=
 tell them "It's okay, let's take it one step at a
time".

Soon, I'll post =
a few additional thoughts on where I see limitations (and
sometimes flaws) =
in TDD and code coverage, and I have no doubt that some of
you will choose =
to interpret that as "Cedric hates TDD" and "Cedric doesn't
believe in code=
 coverage" but I hope the rest of you will see beyond that
and use these ar=
guments to make educated decisions on when and where to use
the best tool f=
or your job.

Because the truth is that there is no silver bullet to write =
good code, and
you should be very skeptical of anyone who is trying to conv=
ince you
otherwise.

-- 
C=E9dric
http://testng.org
